intro: Glia gummifera, commonly known as the gum tree, is a species of flowering plant native to parts of Africa. It belongs to the family Rubiaceae and is characterized by its woody structure and production of a sticky, resinous gum. The plant typically grows in tropical and subtropical regions, often in moist, well-drained soils. Its leaves are usually opposite and elliptical, with a glossy surface, while its flowers are small and clustered in inflorescences. The gum produced by this plant has been used traditionally for various purposes, including medicinal and industrial applications.
